div1.p: The writer makes recommendations concerning how the International Health Board should handle inquiries concerning the status of yellow fever in various South American countries.

div1.head: Letter to Wickliffe Rose, July 22, 1922
div1.opener:
Wateree, S. C.,
July 22/22.
Dr. Wickliffe Rose, General Director,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway,
New York, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Rose:
div1.p:
In answer to your letter of the 12th. inst., relative to the gen-
eral yellow fever situation, I would say:

That I am inclined to think it advisable to send a letter of in-
quiry in the early part of next year to the Health Authorities of the re-
gions which we are not sure are free from yellow fever.

The only objection I can see to so doing would be if the Board were
unwilling in any case to accept a negative reply to this question as
final--i. e. if even with such a reply it should desire to make further
investigation. In that case it might be embarrassing to ask permission to
do this after a negative reply had been received. The regions in the
Americas you mention as not certainly free from yellow fever are those
immediately south of the Caribbean and the Amazon Valley--the latter
doubtless including Para, its sea-port.

I think that with the first it would be well to write also to the
islands in close travel relation with this coast--Curacao: Trinidad:
Barbadoes and the French Antilles: (1) Because they naturally form a
part of the same focus as the eastern Caribbean litoral; and (2), and
more important, from them one should hear of yellow fever in the ports
of the mainland if it exists there.

For the last reason, I would also suggest that the U. S. Quarantine
Officers at Porto Rico and at Colon be asked for such information as they
may have of Venezuelan and Colombian ports respectively. These letters
2.
letters
it would be well to send before the end of this year so as to have this
information before writing the formal letters to the countries on the main-
land.

To give the detail reasons for this opinion: (1) I would accept
negative reports at their face value from the health authorities of Dutch:
British or French colonies--island and mainland. Indeed, the French will
be more apt to report a mild yellow fever where none exists than the con-
trary.

(2) Similarly for a negative report from the Central Health Office
of Colombia, unless contradicted by the Quarantine Office at Colon.

Colombia's communication with infected places has been almost nil.
Her coast towns have been so long without any considerable amount of
yellow fever that if it occurred in them there would be a number of cases--
possibly a small epidemic--and hence recognized and known both to Bogota
and to Colon.

(3) I am inclined to think the same credence should be given to a
negative report from Venezuela. On this, however, I would be glad to
have the opinion of Dr. Guiteras, as he was in Venezuela for much of 1917
working at Coro and elsewhere, and his judgement on this matter should
be worth more than mine.

I would say here that I do not question the good faith of the Central
Health Officers of either Colombia or Venezuela, but I am doubtful of the
results of their investigations of reports of yellow fever. In 1916 we
found that the error of both had been on the side of reporting yellow
fever where none existed: as at Puerto Berrios: the Mines of Muso: Car-
tagena: Caracas and near Maracay, rather than the reverse. I do not know
the official history of the yellow fever which Guiteras saw at Coro in 1917.

On the other hand, I do not think the Port Authorities of Colombia
3.
Colombia
would report yellow fever if they thought (1) that it would lead to quar-
antine by Colon and (2) if it could be concealed. The same has been true
habitually of cities in the U. S.

(4) In 1916 we accepted somewhat similar evidence for the non-exist-
ence of yellow fever in the Amazon Valley. Not quite the same, however,
as the official statement was supplemented by the inquiries of Guiteras
at Para, to which, indeed I, and I believe Dr. Gorgas, gave much weight;
Para being in close commercial and sanitary relation to that Valley.

This Valley--adjudged free in 1916--has been exposed to infection
for some years from that which existed since 1917 on the coast between
Victoria and Pernambuco. I do not know that it has been reported further
north.

Hanson too has mentioned report of yellow fever on the Peruval Ama-
zon. If these be true it would mean a previous infection in Iquitos and
Manaos. The extremely depressed condition of the rubber trade--lessening
immigration into this valley--however, has been a great safe-guard both
against the introduction of infection and the persistence of infection
if introduced--as, indeed, were the considerable epidemics in 1910 to
/13 or /14.

All things considered, I would be willing to rely on the report of
the Central Health Office at Rio in this matter. If yellow fever has re-
turned to the Amazon Valley they should know it. Unless in Manaos it
would soon die out and I doubt if under present, and recent, commercial
conditions it would last indefinitely at Manaos. At any rate, it is of
no greater--indeed of less--importance here than that alleged to be on
the Coast of Brazil.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Address: New Glasgow P. O.,
Amherst County, Va.
“Geddes.”
